author: Atlanta First News staff
title: Surveillance footage captures restaurant burglary in Gwinnett County
text:
Surveillance footage captures restaurant burglary in Gwinnett County
TUCKER, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A destructive burglary was caught on camera in Gwinnett County.
Security cameras captured four men smashing through the window of Chamoy’s Restaurant in Tucker on Sunday.
The owner said the thieves stole his cash register and hundreds of dollars.
“I found the window broken, and almost everything destroyed,” Zoilo Rodriguez Tineo said. “They damaged the payment system and took the cash register.”
The damage totaled about $4,500.
Tineo said it’s not the first time this has happened.
“This is the third time this has happened,” he said. “Still, the police do nothing.”
Police have found the orange Dodge Charger they believe the suspects were driving but have made no arrests. They say this is connected to a string of burglaries in the area.
Copyright 2025 WANF. All rights reserved.
topics: Crime, Law and Justice->robbery and theft

author: Василий Горемыкин
title: В Жигулевске в горящей квартире спасли людей | TLT.ru - Новости Тольятти
text:
9 июля в Жигулевске произошел пожар в одной из квартир дома на улице Морквашинской.
Вызов на пульт огнеборцев поступил в 15:50. На место происшествия были направлены 40 специалистов и 13 единиц техники, сообщает ГУ МЧС по Самарской области.
В 16:37 пожар ликвидирован на площади 20 квадратных метров. В результате происшествия погибших и пострадавших нет, были спасены 2 человека. Самостоятельно эвакуировались 17 человек, в том числе 7 детей.
Причину пожара устанавливают дознаватели МЧС России.

author: Luciana Carvalho
title: Justiça requer de imagens de UPA após paciente morrer à espera de atendimento | Brasil | O Liberal
text:
Justiça requer de imagens de UPA após paciente morrer à espera de atendimento
A Prefeitura do Rio de Janeiro prazo de 48 horas para cumprir a determinação
O Tribunal Regional do Trabalho da 1ª Região, na pessoa da juíza Elisangela Belote Mareto, da 57ª Vara do Trabalho, determinou nesta quinta-feira (19/12) que a Prefeitura do Rio de Janeiro entregue as imagens do circuito interno da UPA da Cidade de Deus, local onde o garçom José Augusto Mota Silva faleceu enquanto aguardava atendimento.
A decisão liminar atende a um pedido do Sindicato dos Auxiliares e Técnicos de Enfermagem do Município do Rio (SATEMRJ), que representa os 20 profissionais de saúde que estavam de plantão no dia da morte do paciente e foram demitidos pela Prefeitura.
A juíza estipulou o prazo de 48 horas para que o município cumpra a determinação, sob pena de multa diária de R$ 200 em caso de descumprimento.
VEJA MAIS
Entenda o caso
O paciente José Augusto Mota Silva, de 32 anos, morreu na noite da última sexta-feira (13/12) à espera de atendimento na UPA da Cidade de Deus, na Zona Oeste do Rio de Janeiro. Testemunhas disseram que o homem chegou à unidade se queixando de fortes dores. A Secretaria Municipal de Saúde do Rio confirmou o caso.
Imagens que circulam nas redes sociais mostram o homem sentando com a cabeça inclinada para a esquerda. Uma pessoa da UPA se aproxima dele, que não reage. Em seguida, José é colocado na maca por um funcionário.
Em nota, a Secretaria Municipal de Saúde (SMS) do Rio informou que o incidente ocorreu de forma muito rápida. O paciente chegou lúcido e andando à unidade, acompanhado por uma pessoa que não permaneceu no local. Após a classificação de risco, às 20h30, ele foi encaminhado para a área de espera de atendimento e encontrado desacordado poucos minutos depois. Levado à Sala Vermelha, José Augusto sofreu uma parada cardiorrespiratória e não resistiu. O corpo foi levado ao Instituto Médico Legal para determinar a causa do óbito.
COMPARTILHE ESSA NOTÍCIA

author: , Oak Ridger
title: Need to get rid of that Bradford pear? Give it to the Knoxville Zoo
text: Need to get rid of those Bradford pear branches? Give it to elephants at the Knoxville Zoo Now that April is here, spring cleaning seems to be in full swing across Knoxville. Yard sales are popping up, and Home Depot and Lowes are being frequented, likely for household project supplies. It's also a time when many choose to give their lawns a sprucing. But what about all the leftover yard trimmings? [Zoo Knoxville's Browse Donations program](https://www.facebook.com/zooknoxville/posts/pfbid02bsNCoULdbgQmL64DqCWbqegL3tqnYd3kXef4pu43dU67bar4xdyiNFkg1cWBaGxHl?__cft__[0]=AZUWx0j71gLEKZ-OUzIhxHoHq4SSuNNL1dSR7LE1EovTomiMozDopCkSD4C--aoWByvZkk3Ff3Ys9OOJJ3FZIRMwqh-BJsA9A9LJh3YUOIvrcGBuG_YYP94rL5WjZA7Y0pIRzpK4QL0ncBMknc8GAo7Lg6-ooz_zK7ddVoas5oYaOUnGaGRutp_Sv9sGUbe6c-2vBBHln0h9B55yL2KZ65yf&__tn__=%2CO%2CP-R) offers a win-win solution. In the wild, giraffes and elephants typically feed on tree branches, also called browse, said lead zookeeper Petty Grieves, who oversees Zoo Knoxville's Grasslands and Asian Trek exhibits. Browse donations from the community can help the zoo replicate this. The zoo uses browse quickly, so there is a frequent need, said J.J. Jones, Zoo Knoxville's media manager. "We regularly ask for donations from the community, because as you can imagine, an elephant eats a lot."While the animals don't rely solely on donated browse for nutrients, it is a food they enjoy eating. "We make sure they have a very balanced diet, but their favorite thing are branches," Grieves said. Among their favorites are the much-maligned Bradford pear, the invasive [Callery pear trees that bloom in spring and give off a stinky fish smell](https://www.knoxnews.com/story/news/local/2024/03/14/why-bradford-pear-trees-smell-bad-and-how-and-why-to-get-rid-of-them/72934322007/). "Our elephant Tonka and our giraffes love to eat browse and bark," said Jones. In addition to providing nourishment, eating browse also serves as a form of enrichment for the animals, Jones told us. What kind of browse can be donated? The species and treatment of the browse matters, but the shape it's in is less important. It's important to the zoo that they don't feed their animals any vegetation that could potentially be toxic, Grieves said. The giraffes and elephants' favorite types of browse are the following, according to Zoo Knoxville's [website](https://zooknoxville.org/browse-donations/): - Bradford pear - Sugar maple - Silver maple - Mulberry - Chestnut oak - White oak - Hickory - Eastern redbud - River birch - Box elder - Elm - Hackberry - Honeysuckle (Not in berry, because they're toxic) - Mimosa - Grapevine - Willow - Tulip poplar The zoo also asks that donors "ensure that any browse has NOT been sprayed with any chemicals or pesticides." Any browse that meets the above guidelines is likely to be a good fit for the zoo, even if it no longer has leaves. Branches without leaves are part of these creatures' diets too, according to Grieves: "They'll strip the bark, and if the branches are thin enough, they'll chew that up and eat that as well." How can browse donations be made? Zoo Knoxville asks that donors call or email before dropping browse off to ensure the zoo is expecting the donation. The zoo does not offer pick up, according to its website. To let the zoo know about a browse donation, call (865) 637-5331, ext. 1280, or email [pgrieve@zooknoxville.org](mailto:pgrieve@zooknoxville.org). Hayden Dunbar is the storyteller reporter. Email hayden.dunbar@knoxnews.com. Support strong local journalism by subscribing at knoxnews.com/subscribe.

author: EFE
title: Una ONG denuncia la muerte de 14 personas en una zódiac al sur de Canarias
text:
Inmigración
Una ONG denuncia la muerte de 14 personas en una zódiac al sur de Canarias
La embarcación, en la que viajaban 58 personas, se ha desinflado a unos 55 kilómetros de la costa marroquí, según Caminando Fronteras, que pide rescatar a los supervivientes
EFE
Al menos catorce personas han muerto ahogadas en una zódiac cuyos ocupantes llevan pidiendo auxilio desde las 14.00 horas de este jueves desde un punto del Atlántico situado a unos 55 kilómetros de Cabo Bojador, en la costa marroquí del Sáhara Occidental, al sur de
[Canarias](/es/temas/islas-canarias-1848283), porque su barca se desinfla y se hunden.
Es la denuncia que realiza la activista Helena Maleno, fundadora de Caminando Fronteras, ONG que lleva toda la tarde de este jueves en contacto con los náufragos y que ha transmitido su posición a las autoridades españolas y marroquíes para que movilicen medios de rescate. Por la localización del incidente, ha asumido la emergencia Rabat.
Maleno ha facilitado a EFE una foto enviada por los supervivientes que todavía siguen a flote, una imagen nocturna y borrosa en la que se ve a entre seis y siete personas sentadas a horcajadas sobre un flotador de una neumática, doblado y medio deshinchado.
Y también un audio que le ha remitido una de las ocupantes de la patera. En él se escucha a una mujer decir en francés: "Estamos aquí, Helena. Soy una mujer embarazada de nueve meses, estoy en el flotador (de la zódiac). Todos los chicos del medio (de la embarcación) han desaparecido, la gente está desapareciendo, hasta ahora no hemos visto a la Marina".
"Toda la gente está desapareciendo. ¡Por favor ayúdennos, ayúdennos! ¡Estamos aquí, ayúdennos! Estamos sentados así en el flotador (se refiere a la imagen que adjunta con el audio). Es muy peligroso, el agua está entrando", se lamenta la mujer
Helena Maleno ha explicado a EFE que, según la información que han recabado sobre esa neumática, se trata de un grupo de 58 personas que salieron el miércoles desde la costa del Sahara hacia Canarias y que ahora se encuentran al suroeste de Cabo Bojador.
Entre ellos, añade, hay siete mujeres (incluyendo a la embarazada) y dos niños.
La portavoz de Caminando Fronteras denuncia que, hasta el momento, Marruecos no ha hecho llegar ayuda a los ocupantes de esa neumática, ni tampoco Salvamento Marítimo español ha intervenido.
Por eso, expresa su temor a que ocurra lo mismo que el 21 de junio, cuando varias personas murieron al hundirse una zódiac al sur de Gran Canaria después de pasar toda la noche esperando a que llegara una patrullera de Marruecos, porque la emergencia la había asumido el Centro de Coordinación de Salvamento de Rabat.
Y ello, a pesar de que un barco de rescate español había estado a solo una hora de distancia de navegación de ellos, socorriendo a otra patera, cuando ya se conocían sus coordenadas.
Ese suceso dio lugar una denuncia de la Fiscalía de Canarias por presunto delito de omisión del deber de socorro contra los responsables del operativo en España, denuncia que desde este verano instruye un Juzgado de Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, que ha declarado secretas las actuaciones.

author: Manuela López Restrepo
title: Katy Perry will be among Blue Origin all-female space crew : NPR
text:
Katy Perry performs during the Super Bowl halftime show at University of Phoenix Stadium on Feb. 1, 2015, in Glendale, Ariz. Now she'll be in space but for real this time. Elsa/Getty Images hide caption
toggle caption Elsa/Getty Images Have you ever thought to yourself, Man, I wish some notable women in pop culture would go explore space sometime soon ? Well, fear not dear reader, because your dreams are coming true.
Three things to know: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos' space exploration company Blue Origin announced its next human flight for its New Shepard program Thursday. The 11-minute suborbital flight is scheduled for sometime this spring.
The crew was selected by Bezos' fiancée and journalist Lauren Sánchez, who will be joined on the spacecraft by Katy Perry, Gayle King and other notable figures: scientist Amanda Nguyen, entrepreneur Aisha Bowe and filmmaker Kerianne Flynn.
Blue Origin says that this is the 11th human flight for the New Shepard program, and the 31st in its history. This is also the first all-female flight crew since Soviet cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova's solo spaceflight in 1963. Sponsor Message

author: Base
title: Canadian Wheat, Canola Production Drops on Dry Conditions | Farms.com
text: Canadian farmers produced less wheat, canola, barley and oats in 2023 due to lower yields in Western Canada where growing conditions were generally drier than in 2022, the production of principal field crops for November 2023 from Statistics Canada said. “Throughout the growing season in 2023, dry conditions across much of Western Canada contributed to lower yields compared with 2022. Warm and dry conditions allowed farm operators to complete harvests in a timely manner across most of the prairies,” a news release on the report said. Canadian wheat production fell by 6.9 per cent to 32 million tonnes with lower yields offsetting the higher harvested area, the report said. In Alberta, wheat yields decreased by 19.6 per cent to 44.7 bushels per acre due to dry conditions in parts of the province. Harvested area rose by 2.4 per cent to 7.7 million acres, resulting in a 17.8 per cent decrease in wheat production to 9.3 million tonnes. Nationally canola production decreased by two per cent to 18.3 million tonnes driven by lower yields. Harvested area rose three per cent to 21.9 million acres. The report noted in Alberta, canola production fell 3.5 per cent to 5.4 million tonnes. The decrease was attributable to lower harvested area while yields edged down 0.5 per cent to 37.9 bushels per acre. Canadian barley production fell 10.9 per cent to 8.9 million tonnes. Total oat production decreased by 49.6 per cent nationally to 2.6 million tonnes in 2023 — the lowest production in more than a decade.
